question: Question_02_(e)
statement:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is
true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If a function is continuous, then it is differentiable.
sols:
A function is non-differentiable if it has a vertical tangent or a sharp
corner (cusp). A function is continuous if it can be drawn in one go
without lifting your pencil. It is possible to draw a continuous
function with one (or multiple!) of the non-differentiable properties
just listed:

\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_2e_cusp_example.jpg}
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_2e_vertical_tangent.jpg}

So a function can be continuous, without necessarily being
differentiable. Thus the statement is false.
hints:
What makes a function non-differentiable? Can you draw a continuous
function with this property?
